content: The Act may be cited as the "Foster Care Mentoring Act of 2003". It includes findings related to foster care. The Foster Care Mentoring Act of 2003 highlights the positive impact of mentors on children in foster care, including improved academic performance, goal achievement, and relationships with adults. It also mentions the high number of young children in the foster care system in 2001. Programs for mentoring children in foster care are being added to the Social Security Act, aiming to provide support and guidance to children in need. The purpose of this section is to authorize grants for mentoring programs for children in foster care, involving a network of public and private community entities. Mentoring is defined as a structured program matching children with trained adult volunteers for one-on-one relationships. The Secretary will award grants to States to support mentoring programs for children in foster care through networks of public and private community entities. Grants may also be awarded directly to political subdivisions serving a substantial number of foster care youth. The Secretary will award grants to States and political subdivisions to support mentoring programs for foster care youth. Application requirements include a program design with a list of participating organizations and qualifications of the overseeing entity. The Secretary will award grants for mentoring programs for foster care youth, including details on mentor-child matches, recruitment methods, background checks, and outcome evaluation. The Secretary requires mentors in the program to undergo intensive training in child development, family dynamics, foster care system, recognizing child abuse, confidentiality, and working with the public school system. The mentor program requires appropriate screening of mentors, including criminal background checks and ensuring their willingness and ability to serve long-term. The mentor program mandates mentors to have a high school diploma or equivalent and at least 1 year of study towards a graduate or postgraduate degree. Additionally, the program must involve community consultation and coordination with other relevant programs. The program must coordinate with Federal, State, and local programs serving children and youth, consult with corrections, workforce development, and substance abuse agencies, and ensure equal access for local service providers. Community organizations, including religious and Indian organizations, can participate equally. The agreement includes maintaining records, reports, and audits for oversight. Cooperation with the Secretary's evaluation of the program is required. The Secretary awards grants for programs under this subsection, covering up to 75 percent of the costs. The State or political subdivision receiving the grant must allocate funds for mentor training and support, with a minimum of 50% for training and ongoing educational support, and a maximum of 10% for administrative purposes. Additional factors may be considered by the Secretary for the success of the mentoring program. The Secretary shall award grants under this section based on the number of children served and the grant amount relative to the need for services, with a maximum limit of $600,000 per State or political subdivision. Procedures for loan discharge applications will be established within 90 days of enactment. Actions will be taken to publicize the program for eligible mentors.
